ratings.question_text: The readings/cases/textbooks used in this course were __________ .
Out-of-class assignments for this course were ___________ to my learning.
The workload for this course in comparison to other courses was ___________.
The pace of this class was ____________ for optimal learning.
Field trips were well designed and ran smoothly.
I learned a lot from field trips.
How clearly does the instructor provide explanations of conceptual material?
How responsive to student comments was the instructor?
I would give the instructor of this class an overall rating of:
I would give this course an overall rating of:
Apart from how well the course was taught, how valuable is the course to students with interests similar to yours?
Did you participate in a work group as part of this course?

narratives.question_text: Use the space below to comment on questions 1-14, if you wish
comments: I took it as a 2 credit course and the workload seemed right for that. My partner took it as a 3 creditclass and was constantly swamped, which made it more difficult for me, though the group dynamic was good over all. I would make the 2 client option 4 credits not 3.

Due to factors like weather and unplanned business trips, we only saw Jim a handful of times over the semester.I felt that the trip down to DC in January was very unnecessary and could have been done by Skype. Think of all the carbon we would save!I only did this course as a "two credit" course, and it was definitely one of my most intensive (time wise) courses I've taken at Yale. I can't imagine taking it as a three credit course and doing two projects.If Jim wants to keep two projects structure, this should definitely be turned into a four credit course.

narratives.question_text: What were the best aspects of this course?
comments: Working on a real project. It was interesting to see what could be done, what should be done, and what was politically feasible.
Jim's network. Guest speakers. Rarely having class.
Hands on experience and coaching from the instructor was invaluable.

The ability to work on (typically) well-conceived, relevant, and sometimes high-profile policy projects for clients that are of interest to job-seeking 2nd years.The projects are truly the stars of the show.

narratives.question_text: What aspects of this course need the most improvement?
comments: The DC trips were rough. They were really badly timed for classwork in other courses and for me spending 8+ hours commuting for a 1 hour meeting seemed like a waste (and I'm sure expensive for the school). I would look into having at least one of the trips be replaced by skype or a teleconference thing or something. Being there in person was unnecessary.
Really should only require one project. I'm not sure the marginal returns of that second project is that high.
More lectures on current events? Or work sessions with instructor on projects? Constant check-ins are helpful. Our group benefited from a very responsive client.

Not all of the projects are equally well-formulated. While some of the projects are precise in scope and expectations for the students and the project sponsor are clear, some projects need further refining and thought before turning over to the students. The difference between a thoughtfully crafted project (by the client sponsor) and a nebulous one is HUGE for the students. It quite literally makes or breaks the student's experience.

narratives.question_text: Was the relationship between the course lectures and discussion/lab section
comments: N/A
N/A

narratives.question_text: Discuss, if you wish, how this course fits into your overall program.  (Please feel free to describe how the course relates to your academic background.)
comments: Having practical experience in something was great. This school doesn't do a whole lot of natural resource stuff that isn't energy.
Interested in policy.
The course is aligned with my experience with and interest in natural resource policy.

narratives.question_text: Why did you take this course?
comments: My interest.
Interested in policy and how its done in the real world.
Because of the opportunity to work on the projects.

narratives.question_text: Did the knowledge/skills that you gained from the course meet your expectations ?
comments: Somewhat. I hoped to get more out of the instructor/classtime than I did but I got a lot out of the over all experience.
Eh, I guess. I ended up not being that interested in my project, but that was my fault.
Yes, it did.

narratives.question_text: If yes, what were the advantages and disadvantages of the group work?
comments: It was challenging but worked out well for the most part. Scheduling things was hard, as was editing the paper together but really nothing too terrible. The main thing was the difference in workloads for the class. Since this was my only project, I felt like I had to take on more work when my partner's other project was struggling.

I was in a group with two other people. One didn't doany work, or became paralyzed in the weeds of a very small problem. The other, I just thank my lucky stars he cared about this project as much as he did.Beyond that, the usual pros and cons of working in groups.

The advantages are division of labor in order to accomplish more research and more writing than I would have otherwise been able to do on my own.The disadvantages were the differences in expectations among team members (particularly with a new member) and the typical challenges associated with team work amongst peers (and friends).

narratives.question_text: For students who might consider taking this course, what advice would you give them?
comments: Take it! Here's hoping you get a good client/project, don't do lots of other group-project based classes at the same time.

If you've already worked in DC, you might not get much out of it. We had one person in our class who had worked in environmental policy in DC and was pretty bored.If you haven't its a great course for getting your feet wet in a real, hands-on course.
This course is a must for any MEM degree candidate.
